Folks with social anxiety/fear of public speaking (both are actual disorders) also stutter but itâ€™s different, they only stutter with certain people and/or in particular situations and thereâ€™s actually a science to it, too, and itâ€™s slightly similar to stuttering as a speech disorder but instead of permanent reduced blood flow in the Brocaâ€™a area, itâ€™s temporary signals being sent to that area that alters the blood flow and hence induce a stutter - I have done my research on this before  and I urge you to look that up. In this case, stuttering is a direct cause of nervousness and thatâ€™s it. Using â€˜stuttering/stutterâ€™ to describe nervous speech causes confusion and I wish the words â€˜stuttering/stutter were never used to describe anything other than stuttering, a neurological speech/disfluency disorder, but unfortunately, it already got out of hand and now everyone thinks â€˜nervous speechâ€™ and â€˜stutteringâ€™ are the same when they are not.

However, when it comes to people who stutter (stuttering as a speech disorder), the cause is neurological - they donâ€™t stutter because and only when they are nervous but also anytime, any place, and with anyone. I know that a lot of stutterers, me included, stutter more severely when we are, for instance, presenting publicly or perhaps communicating with someone we deem significant. Here, nervousness is not the cause of the â€˜stutterâ€™ but a factor that amplifies the â€˜stutterâ€™ and I think the way you describe â€œwe try too hard to speak perfectly and in doing so..â€ falls under this; itâ€™s because we are anxious, we feel pressured, we are uncomfortable, we donâ€™t want to feel different/less than anyone, so we stutter more than we are supposed to or more than we actually do. Thatâ€™s why some people who stutter go to speech therapy, some techniques are utilized to reduce stuttering or reduce the feelings/reactions we get in some situations in which we feel we should overthink our speech and hence stutter more severely! 

I donâ€™t think itâ€™s fair to say â€œa lot of the people that think theyâ€™re stutterers arenâ€™t,â€ it will be as if we are gatekeeping because we all stutter differently and whether our stutter mildly or severely or occasionally, we are still folks who stutter (Iâ€™m not referring to people who stutter due to social anxiety here. Thatâ€™s a different case). If anything, I think there should be an alternative for the word â€˜stutteringâ€™ to describe â€˜nervous speechâ€™ as a result of anxiety/stress/fear of public speaking and not a speech disorder. Itâ€™s  causing so much confusion and unfortunately itâ€™s also trivializing/invalidating the experiences of people who stutter. 

If I may also ask, where did you get that info that the main reason people canâ€™t get their words out is because they â€˜pre-formâ€™ their tongue? I highly doubt that and if I were going to make a long story short, thatâ€™s not applicable to stuttering, at least not as a main cause - as I said nervousness amplifies stuttering and letâ€™s not forget that stuttering could also come with secondary behaviors (eyes closing, moving hands/legs, certain mouth/tongue movements). People donâ€™t stutter because they donâ€™t have â€˜fluidâ€™ tongues; this isnâ€™t the main cause. 

To answer your questions, yes Iâ€™m a person who stutters and I stutter quite often and unpredictably - I donâ€™t only stutter when Iâ€™m giving a presentation but itâ€™s more likely that Iâ€™ll stutter/stutter more when Iâ€™m presenting. I have a set of words that I find difficult to pronounce. I stutter when Iâ€™m talking to my partner, friends, family members, and people Iâ€™m most comfortable with. I have fluent moments/day and I also have days where I stutter more often than I usually do with for no apparent reason. Sometimes I stutter when I talk to myself alone in my room and other times I donâ€™t. I donâ€™t understand my stutter and Iâ€™m not even trying to understand it but definitely trying my best everyday to accept it and not think less of myself because of it. 

I do believe we all stutter differently, approach it differently, experience it differently, feel it differently, and react to it differently!

Thanks for reading all this.

At days when Iâ€™m too tired of having to face up a world where you are expected to speak in a certain way and in a particular pace and where difference is not another way of life/living but a deficit, Iâ€™d say yes, I want to the cure. However most of the time, itâ€™s a no, I donâ€™t want to overcome my stutter (I mean not that I can. I tried!).

Iâ€™m not only my stutter and Iâ€™m not only a stutterer, but stuttering can also be me; itâ€™s a disability (disability as a social construct, meaning itâ€™s something thatâ€™s disabling me because Iâ€™m in a society that has a rigid understandings of whatâ€™s normal and abnormal, hence, my sentences are completed, people are impatient, I may be rejected by some, I may lose a job because of it, I may not be allowed to take part in discussions, I may not be hired, I may not be allowed to have a particular career, I may lose grades as a student, I may not be promoted..etc) and disability is an identity marker. By the way, I understand not all stutterers feel comfortable identifying as disabled, itâ€™s really just a personal choice, but Iâ€™d like them to understand that thereâ€™s no such thing as â€˜real/severe disabilitiesâ€™ and mild disabilities. Disability is not a hierarchy, itâ€™s a spectrum, and itâ€™s also not a slur. 

This toxic and ableist (discrimination against people with disabilities) environment needs to change. We donâ€™t all have to be the same because we were never born the same and were never meant to be the same. 

I wouldnâ€™t know who I would be if I didnâ€™t stutter. It informs my every experience and memory, and therefore, how I see and relate to the world.
